Πέρασαν μέρες και όμως δεν φάνηκε κανένα σημάδι της τρομερής αρρώστιας. Οι μάγοι ξανασυναντήθηκαν για να συζητήσουν το όνειρο και αποφάσισαν ότι τελικά δεν ήταν προφητικό.
Περιπλανόμενη στους δρόμους χωρίς χρήματα ή φαγητό, η γυναίκα σύντομα στράφηκε στο μόνο διαθέσιμο επάγγλεμα για αυτήν.
Πήρε τα χρήματα και δε θα ξαναφανεί στην πόρτα μας ποτέ.
Πήρε χρόνο, αλλά η γη ανάρρωσε και οι σοδειές ξαναφύτρωσαν σε αυτό το κάποτε άγονο έδαφος.

Σκοτώντας τους ηγέτες προκλήθηκε μια ατυχής επίδραση. Ένας άλλος άνδρας, πιο βίαιος και πιο φιλόδοξος, πηρε τον έλεγχο της συμμορίας.
Στα πελάγη συνεχίστηκε η νηνεμία για κάποιο διάστημα, αλλά μετά από λίγο καλοί άνεμοι ξαναφύσηξαν και όλα επέστρεψαν στο φυσιολογικό.
Στην αρχή ο λαός σε κατηγορούσε ότι απέτυχες να αποδώσεις την αρμόζουσα τιμή στον θρυλικό ηνίοχο. Όταν το άγαλμα αποκαλύφθηκε κατενθουσιάστηκαν!

Στις δοξασίες του Ζωροαστρισμού, η λατρεία εστιάζεται στον Αχούρα Μάζντα, το μεγαλύτερο από τα θεϊκά όντα. Αλλά υπάρχει ένα πλήθος αθανάτων θεοτήτων που τον δοξάζουν επίσης. Αυτά τα Αμέσα Σπέντα ‘Γενναιόδωρα Πνεύματα’ προσωποποιούν πολλά χαρακτηριστικά και έχουν δικές τους γιορτές, που είναι γνωστές ως Γιασάν, κατά τη διάρκεια όλου του έτους.

Το Γιασάν του Αρντάβιστ, η γιορτή της φωτιάς, γίνεται προς τιμήν του Άσα, ενός από τα Αμέσα Σπέντα. Ο Άσα αντιπροσωπέυει ένα σύνολο από ανθρώπινα χαρακτηριστικά, με κυριότερο να είναι η αλήθεια που συνδέεται με τη φωτιά. Η φωτιά είναι η δύναμη που δίνει ζωή στα Αμέσα Σπέντα· καίει την αμαρτία, φέρνει επίγνωση και πληροφορεί για την ειλικρινή ομιλία.

Στη Γιασάν του Άρνταβιστ On the Jashan of Ardavisht mighty fires are lit, around which celebrations are made and praise is offered to Asha. It is a time of great joy and divine inspiration; of feasting and togetherness.

Σύντομα διαδόθηκαν φήμες πως ο φύλαρχος δεν μπορούσε να ικανοποιήσει τις συζύγους του. Οι κακεντρεχείς προσβολές του έχασαν την αξία τους στα αυτιά όσων τον άκουγαν.
Σύντομα συγχύζεται και πέφτει σε αντιφάσεις. Ο λαός απολαμβάνει το θέαμα και σύντομα ξεχνά τις ανοησίες του για κακούς οιωνούς.

Τα αίμα νερό δεν γίνεται και οι οικογενειακοί δεσμοί μπορούν να είναι οι ισχυρότεροι. Άσκησες κριτική στον αντίπαλο του, ενώ διακήρυσσες την αθωότητα του εξαδέλφου σου. Αυτό δεν έκανε καλή εντύπωση στους υποστηρικτές σου ή την κοινή γνώμη.

Τα αίμα νερό δεν γίνεται και οι οικογενειακοί δεσμοί μπορούν να είναι οι ισχυρότεροι. Άσκησες κριτική στον αντίπαλο του, ενώ διακήρυσσες την αθωότητα του εξαδέλφου σου. Αυτό δεν έκανε καλή εντύπωση στους υποστηρικτές σου ή την κοινή γνώμη.

Τα αίμα νερό δεν γίνεται και οι οικογενειακοί δεσμοί μπορούν να είναι οι ισχυρότεροι. Άσκησες κριτική στον αντίπαλο του, ενώ διακήρυσσες την αθωότητα του εξαδέλφου σου. Αυτό δεν έκανε καλή εντύπωση στους υποστηρικτές σου ή την κοινή γνώμη.

Τα ακούραστα πνεύματα των νεκρών ήταν μια αληθινή έννοια για το λαό της Ρώμης. Αν οι συγγενείς είχαν ένα βίαιο θάνατο ή δεν λάμβαναν τις ορθές ταφικές τελετουργίες, θα επέστρεφαν ως ‘λάρβαε’, φορείς κακής τύχης στους αμελείς απογόνους. Η γιορτή των Λεμουρίων αφορούσε αυτά τα εκδικητικά πνεύματα. Μια φορά το χρόνο η κεφαλή του νοικοκυριού σηκωνόταν τα μεσάνυχτα, εξάγνιζε το σώμα του και γέμιζε το στόμα του με μαύρα φασόλια. Καθώς κινούνταν μέσα στο σπίτι, έλεγε τα μαγικά λόγια “με αυτά εξιλεώνω εμένα και τους δικούς μου” και έφτυνε τα φασόλια στο πάτωμα, με τα μάτια στραμμένα αλλού, ώστε τα πνεύματα να μπορούν να τα μαζέψουν και να τραφούν από τη μαγική τους ενέργεια. Τελικά, με μια κραυγή “πνεύματα των πατέρων και των προγόνων μου, φύγετε”, ολόκληρο το νοικοκυριό χτυπούσε δοχεία και τηγάνια, διώχνοντας τα πνεύματα στη νύχτα.
Τα άλογα από τη Νισέα δόθηκαν στο στρατό και οι άντρες σέβονταν τα ζώα. Γρήγορα διαδόθηκε η φήμη ότι ήταν μακρινοί συγγενείς του Πήγασου: οι άντρες τα μεταχειρίζονταν με τον υπέρτατο σεβασμό.

Τα άλογα δόθηκαν στους καλύτερους πολεμιστές μας. Αυτοί σέβονταν τα ζώα. Διαδόθηκε γρήγορα η φήμη ότι ήταν ένα ευλογημένο δώρο από τη θεά των αλόγων και οι άντρες τα μεταχειρίζονταν με τον υπέρτατο σεβασμό.

Τα αποβράσματα σύντομα άρχισαν να μάχονται μεταξύ τους, χωρισμένοι σε δύο πλευρές. Η μάχη ήταν αιματηρή και οι δύο πλευρές είχαν βαριές απώλειες, μην αφήνοντας κανέναν αρκετά ισχυρό να κρατήσει τα λιμάνια. Η προμήθεια σιτηρών στη Ρώμη συνεχίστηκε κανονικά.

Τα αποβράσματα σύντομα άρχισαν να μάχονται μεταξύ τους, χωρισμένοι σε δύο πλευρές. Η μάχη ήταν αιματηρή και οι δύο πλευρές είχαν βαριές απώλειες, μην αφήνοντας κανέναν αρκετά ισχυρό να κρατήσει τα λιμάνια. Η προμήθεια σιτηρών στη Ρώμη συνεχίστηκε κανονικά.
Τα βιβλία της Σίβυλλας! Αυτά τα δώρα των θεών περιείχαν πολλά για το μέλλον μας. Πριν χαθεί μέσα στη νύχτα, η ξένη γριά προειδοποίησε ότι πρέπει να φυλάσσονται προσεκτικά.
Τα θαύματα της μακρινής ανατολής περιγράφονται σε τόμους βιβλίων που βρήκαν το δρόμο τους για τις ακτές σου.

Τα Θεσμοφόρια έφτασαν! Παντρεμένες γυναίκες φεύγουν από τα σπίτια τους για τα περίχωρα, λούζοντας το σώμα τους για να εξαγνιστούν και θυσιάζοντας χοίρους στη Δήμητρα και την Περσεφόνη. Οι νύχτες ζωντανεύουν με τις φωτιές, καθώς γλεντούν και γιορτάζουν. Ίσως εφέτος να δούμε μια παράσταση της Λυσιστράτης ή των Θεσμοφοριαζουσών;
Τα κέρδη από το νέο φόρο των ναών ήταν καλά, αλλά ο λαός ήταν εξοργισμένος. Πίστευαν ότι εκμεταλλευόσουν την αγάπη τους για τους θεούς για τους δικούς σου σκοπούς.
Τα λύτρα πληρώθηκαν και η σύζυγος του στρατηγού επέστρεψε με ασφάλεια σε εκείνον. Ήταν εξαιρετικά ευγνώμων και υποσχέθηκε το αγέννητο παιδί του στην υπηρεσία σου.
Τα νέα για τη θεϊκότητα του διοικητή διαδόθηκαν. Ο λαός άρχισε να αμφισβητεί το δικαίωμα του βασιλιά να κυβερνά: δεν πρέπει ο κληρονόμος του Δία να είναι ο αφέντης των πάντων;
Τα νέα για τη θνητότητα του βασιλιά έφτασαν στα αυτιά του λαού. Κάποιοι λένε ανοιχτά ότι δεν είναι ο Αλέξανδρος· άλλοι αμφισβητούν το δικαίωμα του να κυβερνά.
Τα νέα για την εξαφάνιση της γυναίκας σύντομα διαδόθηκαν και δεν πήρε πολύ οι κατηγορίες να φτάσουν στην πόρτα σου, ένας λεκές στο όνομα της οικογένειας.

Τα νέα για το ειδεχθές έγκλημα διαδόθηκαν και ο όχλος ορκίστηκε εκδίκηση για δολοφονημένο αγόρι. Έσυραν τον άνδρα έξω από το σπίτι του μέσα στη νύχτα και τον έκαναν να πληρώσει για τα εγκλήματα του, επανειλημμένα.

Τα νέα για το ειδεχθές έγκλημα διαδόθηκαν και ο όχλος ορκίστηκε εκδίκηση για δολοφονημένο αγόρι. Έσυραν τον άνδρα έξω από το σπίτι του μέσα στη νύχτα και τον έκαναν να πληρώσει για τα εγκλήματα του, επανειλημμένα.

Τα νέα για το κοίτασμα διαδόθηκαν και οι λόφοι γέμισαν από κόσμο που ήλπιζε να το εκμεταλλευτεί. Πολλοί ήταν παντελώς άπειροι μεταλλωρύχοι και οι βιαστικά φτιαγμένες και ελλιπείς σε συντήρηση στοές σύντομα κατέρρευσαν, σκοτώνοντας όλους όσους ήταν μέσα.
Τα νέα γρήγορα έφτασαν στον έπαρχο και γρήγορα χώρισε με τη γυναίκα, αφήνοντας την άπορη.

Τα οστά του Γρύπα βγήκαν σε επίδειξη και ο κόσμος συσσωρευόταν για να τα δει. Τα νέα της ανακάλυψης τους διαδόθηκαν και οι κλοπές στα ορυχία μειώθηκαν, καθώς οι κλέφτες φοβούνταν την οργή των γρυπών που φυλάνε τους θησαυρούς βαθιά μέσα στη γη.

Τα ουράνια αλλάζουν και έρχονται οι εορτασμοί για τα Πάνδια! Δοξάζουμε τον Δία και τα παιδιά του, τον ύψιστο των θεών και αυτόν που αξίζει περισσότερο την τιμή μας. Καθώς φτάνουμε στο άκρο του Ελαφοβολίωνα, οι ζεστές ημέρες και οι δροσερές νύχτες θα κάνουν την ανοιξιάτικη γιορτή αυτού του έτους αξέχαστη!

Τα Παναθήναια - ένα θέαμα για όλο τον κόσμο! Τιμούμε και θυσιάζουμε στους θεούς καθώς οι αγώνες λαμβάνουν χώρα. Κατά τους εορτασμούς θα πραγματοποιηθεί μια λαμπαδηδρομία, όπως επίσης διαγωνισμοί ποίησης και μουσικής. Τελειώνοντας με μια αρματοδρομία, η κλιμάκωση των αγώνων είναι βέβαιο πως θα  συζητείται ως την επόμενη χρονιά!
Τα παράξενα έθιμα και τα όμορφα τοπία της Αιγύπτου φτάνουν σε εμάς, γραμμένα από έναν φιλόπονο ταξιδιώτη.
Τα πελάγη είναι αχανή και ακόμα και το ισχυρότερο ναυτικό δε μπορεί να τα ελέγξει. Η πειρατεία κλιμακώθηκε: ως αποτέλεσμα το εμπόριο υποφέρει.
Τα πλήθη συγκεντρώθηκαν για να παρακολοθήσουν την τιμωρία του φονιά. Το ζητωκραύγασμα όταν τον έριξαν από τον Τάρπειο Βράχο ήταν εκκωφαντικό.
Τα πλήθη συγκεντρώθηκαν για να παρακολοθήσουν την τιμωρία του φονιά. Το ζητωκραύγασμα όταν τον έριξαν από τον Τάρπειο Βράχο ήταν εκκωφαντικό.
Τα σκοτεινά κύματα φουσκώνουν και οι κεραυνοί σχίζουν τους ουρανούς! Θύελλες σαρώνουν τους ωκεανούς. Πλοία καταστρέφονται και άντρες πνίγονται στα κύματα, βορά στους θεούς και τα τέρατα του βυθού.

Τα τείχη δεν μπορούν να αντέξουν για πάντα. Οι άντρες μέσα από αυτά, που τα υπερασπίζονται, είναι αυτοί που τα κρατούν ασφαλή. Σε αμέτρητες περιστάσεις, αυτός ο ρωμαλέος στρατιώτης έδρασε ηρωικά και με μεγάλη πονηριά, οδήγησε τους υπερασπιστές στη νίκη ξανά και ξανά. Αληθώς, είναι ένας ήρωας και σωτήρας!

Τα χέρια του τεχνίτη είναι ευλογημένα από την Αθηνά! Είναι τα Χαλκεία, όταν τιμάμε εκείνη και τους μεταλλουργούς μας επίσης. Ο μέγας αργαλειός ήδη κατασκευάζεται και θα επανδρωθεί από τους νεαρούς αρρεφόρους. Είναι επίσης καιρός για προετοιμασία, καθώς κατά τη διάρκεια των εορτασμών θα υφάνουμε τον μέγα πέπλο για τη γιορτή των Παναθηναίων που θα ακολουθήσει.

Τα χρήματα από αυτά τα εντυπωσιακά ζώα συνέχισαν να ρέουν στα χέρια σου. Ωστόσο, όσο το αίμα των αλόγων από τη Νισέα αδυνάτιζε ο κόσμος έπαψε να φοβάται το ιππικό σου. Η θρυλική ποιότητα των αλόγων της Νισέας έγινε ανάμνηση.

Τε εμπόριο των αλόγων από τη Νισέα συνεχίστηκε όπως πάντα. Δεν υπήρχε κάτι που να απαιτεί την προσοχή σου.
Τίποτα δεν έγινε, όπως αναμενόταν. Είμαστε πιστοί στους θεούς, γιατί θα πρέπει να μας τιμωρήσουν;
Τίποτα δεν έγινε. Φαίνεται πως οι θεοί είναι ικανοποιημένοι.
Το αγόρι έγινε ένας αξιοσέβαστος ιερέας και οι θεοί ήταν ευγνώμονες στην οικογένεια μας που έστειλε το αγόρι στο ναό.
Το αγόρι έγινε σπουδαίος πολεμιστής και αυτός, και ο κάπρος του, έγιναν θρύλος.

Το αγόρι εκτελέστηκε και η μητέρα του έκλαψε για την απώλεια του. Μετά από αυτό, άλλα νεαρά μέλη της οικογένειας διόρθωσαν τη συμπεριφορά τους. Η μοίρα του αγοριού έγινε μάθημα για όσους έχουν κακή διαγωγή.
Το αγόρι εξαφανίστηκε και δεν ειπώθηκε τίποτα παραπάνω για αυτό το περιστατικό.
Το αγόρι εξαφανίστηκε και δεν ειπώθηκε τίποτα παραπάνω για αυτό το περιστατικό.

Το αγόρι επέστρεψε στην αυλή και ήταν υπόδειγμα συμπεριφοράς. Η μητέρα του ήταν ευγνωμονούσα και έκανε ότι μπορούσε για να σε υποστηρίξει, ακόμα και όταν οι μουρμούριζαν ότι δεν άξιζε τη συγχώρεση σου.
Το αγόρι επέστρεψε στο σπίτι του στην εξορία και σύντομα συνέχισε την ακόλαστη ζωή του. Η μητέρα του ταπεινώθηκε και δεν ξαναανέφερε το όνομα του γιου της.
Το αγόρι ήταν πολλά υποσχόμενο. Η δεξιότητα του στα όπλα ήταν απαράμιλλη και εκπαίδευσε ακόμα και τον κάπρο του για να επιτίθεται στους εχθρούς του.
Το αγόρι προπονούταν ακούραστα και σπούδασε με κάποια από τα σπουδαιότερα μυαλά της εποχής του. Καθώς μεγάλωνε έγινε προφανές ότι θα επιτύγχανε μεγάλα επιτεύγματα.

Το αγόρι συνέχισε να ντροπιάζει την οικογένεια με τις ακόλαστες πράξεις του. Η μητέρα του τον υπεραγαπούσε και έπεισε τον εαυτό της ότι ήταν πλέον καλό παιδί, αλλά η υπόλοιπη οικογένεια γνώριζε και αμφισβητούσε την κρίση σου.

Το αγόρι το πλήρωσε. Αφού πλήρωσε ένα σημαντικό ποσό για να εξασφαλίσει τη σιωπή μας, δεν ήταν, δυστυχώς, σε θέση να πληρώσει τους λιγότερο επιλήψιμους πιστωτές του. Όταν προσπάθησε να διαπραγματευτεί μαζί τους, του πήραν τη ζωή ως αποζημίωση για τα χρέη του.
Το αγόρι το υιοθέτησε και το ανέθρεψε η οικογένεια μας. Καθώς μεγάλωνε γινόταν ολοένα πιο εμφανές ότι η γυναίκα ήταν ειλικρινής: το παιδί ήταν πραγματικά ομοαίματο μας.

Το ανόητο αγόρι απελευθερώθηκε και γύρισε στο σπίτι της οικογενείας του καυχούμενο για το τεράστιο ποσό που είχε πληρωθεί για να εξασφαλιστεί η απελευθέρωση του. Αφού τον επέπληξε ο πατέρας του, θυμήθηκε ποια είναι η θέση του και δεν προκάλεσε ξανά προβλήματα στην οικογένεια.
Το βρέφος και η μητέρα του απομακρύνθηκαν και ο λαός ανάσανε με ανακούφιση.

Το δέκατοέκτο γεμάτο φεγγάρι σηματοδοτεί τη γιορτή της Μουνιχίας. Με μεγάλη χαρά, ενθυμούμαστε τη νίκη μας επί των Περσών στη Σαλαμίνα και την επιβίωση του πολιτισμού μας. Κουλούρια με κεριά, προσφέρονταν στην Άρτεμη ως δείγμα ευγνωμοσύνης. Επίσης, νεαρά κορίτσια ντύνονταν ως αρκούδες για… 'μυστήριους' λόγους…

Το κορίτσι αρπάχθηκε από την αγορά και την πήραν ένα μέρος που είχε μια ήσυχη συζήτηση με έναν άνδρα και την κοφτερή λεπίδα του. Έγινε πολύ ομιλητική και οι πληροφορίες που πήραμε από αυτήν ήταν αρκετές για να καταστρέψουμε την υπόληψη του αντιπάλου μας για πάντα.
Το κορίτσι θανατώθηκε ήσυχα, αλλά τα νέα διαδόθηκαν. Ο κόσμος ψιθύριζε πως η οργή σου ήταν τρομερή για όποιον την προκαλούσε!
Το κορίτσι στάλθηκε μακριά και της απαγορεύτηκε να επικοινωνήσει με τον Έλληνα εραστή της.  Η συμπεριφορά της ήταν δημοφιλές κουτσομπολιό για κάποιο καιρό, αλλά δεν ξαναντρόπιασε την οικογένεια.

Το κορίτσι σωστά μας υπέδειξε ότι τα χρήματα δεν της ήταν χρήσιμα. Οι αφέντες της θα αναρωτιούνταν που τα βρήκε και θα υπέθεταν τα χειρότερα. Δεν μπορούσαμε να την πείσουμε να αποκαλύψει τα μυστικά της.

Easter

It is early in the morning. I clasp the last buckle of my armour. The wolf cloak is warm and heavy on my shoulders. I step out and breath the cool air. The warriors before my hall turn towards me - all of them, young and old, Greuthungi and Tervingi. I begin talking but a roar overwhelms me. It is them; my Gothic warriors. In the frontline I see Geberic, his sword naked in the morning sun. They all chant the name of their reiks - my name Cannabaudes! Cannabaudes! Cannabaudes!" I then climb on my horse and lead. And they\? They follow."

I know much. I have seen a lot. I have felt rage. I have felt pain. I marched south behind Cniva, across the great river. I slew Romans, took their gold and torched their homes. That was a long time ago; now I am old. There is frost, deep in the marrow of my bones. Yet I am reiks of the Gothi now; my sword arm is still strong. I watch the young ones. I see they doubt me. They doubt my strength and doubt my wits. I must disperse their doubts. I will lead them further than Cniva did. I will make them richer than Cniva did. When they grow old, they will be proud to say they marched behind Cannabaudes.

The Carthaginian officials solemnly express their gratitude as the murderer is dragged off to their ship, never to be seen again. In a few days, filthy scrawlings appear on alley walls around the city. Their author implies that improper relations between you and a group of Carthaginian nobles.

The Carthaginian messengers are told that the culprit died in an accident. At first they do not believe it, then they have questions. Finally, they grow impatient, then furious, then they curse. Finally, they leave. That very same evening a sizeable anonymous donation arrives at your treasury. The young murderer is safe...

This young prophet has something of the divine about him; he talks to our people like the forefathers who established our great people. Day by day, their pride in our achievements grows - our troops will march to victory and glory once again!

The most important of Christian holidays is in March, celebrating the resurrection of Jesus Christ. This gives hope to Christians that when they die, they too will be resurrected in heaven. It gives people solace and the will to endure this troubled time. People in the province rejoice!
Ancestors, be praised! We have managed to bag a large quantity of treasure! Our warband approached the city's outskirts under cover of darkness; Carthage never saw us coming... Or indeed going!

The raid was a moderate success. The city reinforcements arrived on time, which forced our men to flee before they had completed their mission. We were able to steal some supplies, but Carthage will definitely remember this!

Seven days in April; this is the length of ‘Cerealia,’ the festival in honour of our beloved Ceres. To ensure her benevolence, we celebrate in a fashion worthy of her divine stature. Each night we perform the ritual, whereby torches are attached to the tails of foxes and they are allowed to run about, symbolically cleansing the growing crops. Votive games are also held, and there are female dancers, dressed all in white. As you might expect, plenty of wine accompanies it all!
The young war chief, eager to prove himself, accepted his ruler's will without further objection. However, his men have now grown restless and caused some commotion regarding the matter!

May all their horses be lame! A neighbouring tribe has beaten us to our prize and have stolen \*our\* rightful plunder. Enticed by rumours that Carthage currently lies defenceless, the Gaetuli tribe have sent a warband against the city! Although they weren't able to take much they have successfully blamed the raid on us - this is an outrage!
Soldiers in full battle regalia stand guard before the tomb, day and night, until the populations' fears dissipate.
The priest is slightly inebriated while he reads the lightning. He discerns that it predicts a great feast that will happen that very evening. Oh well...

After depositing the required sum, the man is set free. The general populace approves of your decision, but the nobles grumble that now there's nothing to stop this criminal from performing the ritual again.

No expense is spared; ordinary citizens in your capital enjoy a week-long festival, with free wine and tender, roasted meats. After the communal hangover passes, everyone on the street praises your governmental skill.

The tomb might be cursed or it might not. The matter of real importance is the valuable objects it contains. Your men manage to sneak them out; however, word of the operation gets out and the other political powers grow discontented.
The priest announces that Sethlans sent the lightning to show exactly how hard and often a smith should strike his anvil. Pious smiths everywhere seek to emulate this divine prowess.

The man accepts his fate, watching as your men attach a plate with his name on it to a tomb. Days and weeks pass, yet the man is still alive and healthy. Over time, the whole story is gradually forgotten.
No expense is spared; the sacrifices do not stop and thick columns of smoke rise day and night from the altars. The news of this event travels far.
The locals are pleased with your decision to leave the tomb undisturbed. Some of them, however, choose to leave their homes, fearing the ancient curse contained within.

The priest reads the lightning and announces that Tinia is displeased with the lawlessness across the land. Unless people act honestly, the god will surely smite us. Surprisingly enough, many pay heed to his words.
After the man is put to death, the noblemen express their gratitude at the swiftness of your justice. At the same time, amongst themselves many locals call you a tyrant.

No expense is spared; food is imported from abroad, the dancers hired are the best in the whole of Etruria, and several fantastic musicians are brought in from Greece. All the nobles admire your generosity and taste.

During a grand ceremony, master builders seal the tomb under a pile of heavy stone blocks. While the noblemen approve of the action, as nobody made an attempt to seize the treasure inside, tampering with the tomb has made the commoners rather uneasy.

The priest explains that the storm has one meaning: war! War is coming; it will be brutal, and only the bravest will live to tell of it, as Laran himself will watch over them. To the gathered throng. all this sounds rather plausible...
It is decided - the feast is to be postponed indefinitely. At least the treasury remains full and nothing was spent on pointless entertainment.

The Helvetii!
The Helvetii!

Wine holds something of a special status for us. It provides both a mystical connection to the divine and a key to a happy mortal existence. With the festival of ‘Vinalia Rustica’ we celebrate the fertility of our land and pray for an abundant grape harvest, so we may have wine for the coming year. Both Jupiter and Venus are closely connected to proceedings. Jupiter, of course, controls the weather, and allows the vines to grow. For him, we reserve the first bunch of grapes of the season; Venus is the patron of wine intended for everyday use, and indeed daily rites are conducted at her temples during festival time.

We gathered what we could but most farms were destroyed by the passing plague of locusts.
The smoke and effluvium have warded off the throng. A small win, then, but at what cost\? Our farms are saved but our precious frankincense is lost!
We dispatched our swiftest envoy to obtain the expensive cure. Although our coffers are now empty, our camels continue to live, and can fill them again!

We've arranged for our neighbours to 'stumble upon' a pack of 'lost' camels. With the ensuing outbreak we've hampered their ability to trade effectively! \n\nWe can’t always deal with calamity but are rather adept at causing it!

A seer from a faraway village has been brought to the pens, where he has wandered around, muttering to himself and boiling substances with which to treat the livestock. In the end, the disease was snuffed out… like magic!

A pack of experienced hunters were sent to deal with the beast. It took them an entire week and more than a few broken bones, but finally the creature was put down. Its skin will serve as a trophy for the ruling family! Work can continue here once again.

The local priests organised a hunting party to seek out and kill the creature! It was caught, sacrificed and mummified at great cost, then placed in a special, newly-built, ornately-decorated room in the local temple.

It turns out that the local priests are regularly feeding the monster as part of a religious ceremony in praise of Sobek, the Nile god. Maybe the god has smiled upon us\? The beast seems satiated and has left our fishermen alone…
The Massalians do little to protest your decision to make them the least favoured in your markets. Traders of other states, however, are delighted, and flock to sell and buy in droves.
The decision to reject the Massalian offer is lauded by the commoners. The most vocal among them claimed that they hated those damned Massalian vases and sticky perfumes" anyway!"

Pax Romana

My story was long. I described the huntsmen, our horses, our ride through the woods, the pursuit of the wolves, the twang of bow strings, the whimper of the beasts and the weight of their bodies as I slung them on my horse. When I finished, everyone was silent in the hall. Geberic did not dare meet my gaze.

I explained everything. The Romans tried to hold their ground. They knew how to fight. I ran towards their battleline. My heart pounded in my chest. I smelled blood and sweat. My ears rang with our war cry. We smashed against their line. Once, twice, thrice even, and I saw them waver. They broke, they ran and they died. By the end of my tale, people in the hall were cheering. Geberic had joined them.

My story was long. I described in details my preparations: the sharpening of stakes, the choice of location, the setting of bait, the two dead beasts I found the next day. When I finished, everyone was silent in the hall. Geberic did not dare meet my gaze.

The old reiks quickly came alive in my mind and my tale flowed. I remembered well his bravery in combat. His singular might, his terrifying voice, his horrid cruel treatment of his enemies, his battle axe that was so heavy only he could lift it. The memories were painful. All of this was so long ago. Tears welled in my eyes. I drove them away. The story was over.

I explained everything. The Romans were completely unaware of us. From between tree trunks and branches I watched them. They looked tired, their armour battered and their cloaks were covered in grime and blood. Then we were upon them. Every man I slew that day had the look of surprise on his face. By the end of my tale, people in the hall were cheering. Geberic had joined them.

The old reiks quickly came alive in my mind and my tale flowed. I remembered well his commanding presence, his voice as he urged his men to fight and his banner fashioned from a captured Roman Eagle. The memories were painful. All of this was so long ago. Tears welled in my eyes. I drove them away. The story was over.

My story was long. I described in detail the fight: the snarling of the wolves, the breaking of my spear, their warm breath, my sharp knife and their steaming blood that melted the snow. When I finished, everyone was silent in the hall. Geberic did not dare meet my gaze.

I explained everything. The Romans advanced towards our line. We stood to face them, our shields tightly interlocked. Our honour was unbreakable. We met the hail of javelins and arrows without flinching. Their attack was a gust of wind upon a rock. I remembered the sudden blare of their horns. They retreated, their wounded at our mercy. By the end of my tale, people in the hall were cheering. Geberic had joined them.

The old reiks quickly came alive in my mind and my tale flowed. I remembered well his sharp wit, his eyes that noticed every little thing around him and his speech that could convince you of deeds unthinkable. The memories were painful. All of this - so long ago. Tears welled in my eyes. I drove them away. The story was over.

I did not lie to him. What point was there in promises I might not keep\? This was all I knew. The Gothi would survive, and while there was still a drop of blood in my veins and a whiff of breath in my chest, I would do whatever was required of me. This was what everyone of us had to do. Geberic looked smitten. He thanked me and left, leaving me by the smoking ashes of the fire.

The old reiks quickly came alive in my mind and my tale flowed. He was my leader - my friend. I told the truth: Cniva was fond of drinking, he fought Romans and treacherous steppe men, yet a hangover was his real enemy. The memories brought me joy. All of this was so long ago. I smiled as I talked and so did many others in the hall. The story was over.

I spoke of gold. I spoke of fine cloth, gems and rare spices. The world around us held treasure beyond measure. The Gothi were not traders, I reminded him. We were warriors, brigands and raiders. Everything we desired we could purchase with the edges of our swords. This was our sole destiny. Geberic looked smitten. He thanked me and left, leaving me by the smoking ashes of the fire.

I explained everything. The outlook was grim. For every Gothic warrior, the Romans had three. Furthermore, our Alani mercenaries switched sides right before the battle. I saw all this. I knew there would be no victory even if Gaut himself came to aid us. I gathered my own fighters, my kin. I led them away from the field. Many others did the same that day. To my surprise, Geberic then interrupted me. You saved your men that day," he says as if happy with the realisation. I gave him a nod."

I spoke of lands near and far. I reminded Geberic of where we had been: the north, the homeland of Gaut; the south and west, the cities of the 'civilised' people; the east and the secrets concealed there. All of these would belong to the Gothi one day. I would not see this day and neither would Geberic, but the children of his children shall live like the Romans did long ago. Geberic looked smitten. He thanked me and left, leaving me by the smoking ashes of the fire.

My story was long. I describe in details my lonely journey: the merchant and his camp in a cave, plus the magnificent pelts he sold for a bargain. When I finished I heard people giggling at Geberic, for some reason. He looked offended. If you do not want us to know, you should have told us so." He then left."

I spoke of Romans and their delusions of greatness. Their time had come, the Empire was in agony. It was up to me, Cannabaudes, to slit its throat. And by Gaut, Teiws, Jupiter and every other god, I intended to do so. So I swore and then Geberic swore as well. Then he swiftly left, leaving me by the smoking ashes of the fire.
Sparta has won!

Rome is dying. These words I hear every day. Whenever we see the desolation the barbarians leave in their wake, someone whispers Rome is dying". When we enter battle and rout the barbarians, there will be hushed talks, murmuring "Still, Rome is dying". No more! Rome has been dying for as long as I remember. I saw its agony, the rot eating through it from within. No more! My soldiers have chosen me to be their Emperor and I will be an Emperor worthy of their trust. Sol Invictus! Lord of daylight! I offer neither sacrifice, nor solemn oath. I am not a man of empty promises. I ask only this: watch over my wife and daughter, my Legions, the people of Rome. For if its light goes out, what will become of you - of us\? Forgotten shadows from a past, drenched in gore. I, Lucius Aurelian, will not have this!"

Rome is not dead. These words I hear every day. A soldier, succumbing to his wounds, breathes out his last with these very words. After chasing down the last foes in a battle, as we ride back to camp, my Legions yell all around me. Their voices proclaim loud and clear that Rome is not dead. Our struggle was long and still the war is far from over. Victory is still uncertain. Our future might hold dread surprises for us - defeat and suffering. But Rome is not dead! Do you hear me, Sol Invictus, glowing sun eternal! Rome is not dead! Rome shall never die!

The animals turned out to be highly sought-after possessions that have boosted commerce. Unfortunately, they've also turned out be infected with disease, which has spread throughout the province. The health of the local populace has drastically deteriorated as a result.
You politely decline the offer for trade and send the foreigners on their way. The port traders are not happy, but at least you've kept your cities safe from foreign diseases!

Denying trade has upset the local merchants, who have spent the following days complaining about the missed opportunity. The foreigners have sailed away now, but their stay only made our harbours filthier.

The appropriated animals were added to your personal collection, boosting your family's splendour. Some of the animals turned out to be infected by a disease, the impact of which has fortunately been mitigated by the limited number of people with access to the cages.
The slavemaster leaves in a fury, threatening that every man in Carthage will stand, sword in hand, to punish this outrageous decision. Simple words, nothing more... hopefully.

The slavemaster and his men resist, but to no avail. After losing their slaves, they should consider themselves lucky they've been allowed to escape with their lives! Carthage might be angry but, really, aren't they always\?
It takes the slave master only a few weeks to finish his business. He sets sail for Carthage, the holds of his ships empty, leaving an abundance of slaves to do someone else's work for them.

The slavemaster accept the payment with a smile and leaves, promising to return again and say a few good words before the Carthaginian shophets, who just happen to be personal friends of his... Meanwhile, the slaves are put to work.

This member of the family has lost most of their slaves to sickness. They are looking for a way to appease the gods and turn this string of bad occurrences around.
This member of the family has fallen prey to the evil eye! They look weakened and shaken, have no appetite and feel like something is draining away their lifeforce.

A mocking poem about this family member was written by an unknown hand. Delighted, they now tell everybody they've been immortalised in such a comic fashion.

The evening turned into a celebration of intellect and quick wits. It was one of those merry nights which would later become the stuff of legend.

This member of the family was told by astrologers that they were born under a lucky star. Good luck is contagious, so there is a chance their good fortune will spill over and benefit the rest of the family.
This member of the family was caught in a heavy sea-storm while travelling. Convinced that they survived due to the mercy of the god of the sea, they now embrace him as their household god.

This family member is feeling melancholic, having read a lot of poetry and having had vivid, lucid dreams. This means they are mostly absent, in mind at least, when there are family matters to discuss.
It appears that this family member is not attracted to members of the opposite sex. They say they are aware of their duties but cannot accommodate a spouse or child.
This member of the family has become convinced that they are barren and unable to produce offspring. As a result, they progressively lose their vigour and hope for starting a family.

This family member was a guest to a dinner, given by an exotic eastern trader. They were served a type of wine which was apparently enchanting. Now, our kin refuses to drink any other type of liquid. Annoyance is in the air everywhere they go.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing basic and advanced phalanx tactics.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing seamanship and shipbuilding techniques.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing the importance and intricacies of cavalry management.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing the art of the successful siege assault.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing architectural traditions and innovation.
The philosophers at the court have worked diligently to produce a treatise discussing how best to achieve a bountiful harvest.
This family member gained a reputation for an experienced lover. Even though the society frowns upon such reputation, there are many curious and willing to test first hand if it is well deserved.
This family member has just fallen down some stairs. Having broken a leg, they are now are required to keep to their bed and refrain from public life for several months.

This family member has developed a successful gambling habit, even managing to strip a few noblemen of their purses at a recent dinner! To be a successful gambler requires the ability to read human nature. The same goes for politicians...

In recent months, this family member has developed a following by prophecising great fortunes for people who listen to their preachings. The larger the audience, the more outspoken our family member becomes. They are now taking offerings from their followers. Needless to say, these offerings are accepted only in the form of precious items and coins.

This family member has a high opinion of their own intellect and sees riddles as a way to prove their superiority. Recently, they were challenged by a rival to solve a riddle of the highest difficulty. Since then, no one has seen them. Expectations are that in time they will appear in public, but not necessarily announcing a result.

This member of the family suffered an illness accompanied with high fever and chest pains, also producing minor amounts of blood when coughing. The entire family was prepared to bid farewell to the poor soul. Miraculously, they recovered and are now thankful to the gods and indeed the world. They become open and generous. You only live once," they say with a smile."

A servant from the house of a rival family has been discussing their secrets in the market. This member of our family was present and managed to absorb the valuable information. They have always displayed an instinct for the finest aspects of the political game.

This family member was attacked by their own slaves and was lucky to escape with their life. Shaken and beaten, they claim that the attack was unprovoked, although we have known about their cruelty for a long time.
This family member was attacked and robbed on the street. Shaken and beaten, they feel depressed and have lost some of their enthusiasm.

This family member was attacked in the streets in an attempted robbery. Although they were able to repel the attack easily, they feel aggravated and angry. Not knowing who the attackers were, obviously, makes their anger hard to quench.

The rescue expedition found the animals and their cargo intact but, strangely, not a single living soul. It's likely that the group lost its direction and integrity during the storm and the sand covered their remains... Our scouts searched the area for days and all they found was glittering white sand, an indifferent wind, and twelve dead snakes!

Our priests asked the gods for guidance and protection to bring the lost back into the fold…\n\nHowever, the travellers never arrived. Regardless, we are certain the gods will not allow such misfortune to befall us again.
The druids roam your land, singing of times long gone by, of King Bellovesus and his bravery. Many people start to learn the songs off by heart.
The druids roam your land, urging the people to till the land together. As a result, the grateful earth gives a bountiful harvest.
The druids roam your land, soothing the minds and souls of the people. All is calm after they pass.
The druids roam your land, yet their words sound unconvincing to many. After they pass, people are slightly less convinced that they really are the gods' divine messengers.
The druids roam your land, urging the youngsters to abandon childhood's foolish games and take up the sword. As a result, many young men flow into your forces, either to fight or just to help.
The druids roam your land, promoting the importance of friendly relations with foreigners. As a result, your people gain a reputation for being slightly more amicable than the average Gaul.
The druids roam your land, organising war-dancing competitions. Many of the most skilled dancers are handpicked by the druids to join your troops.
This family member is a hard worker. They recently announced that they had come up with an organisational idea which allowed them to achieve higher results without increasing the manpower.
This member of the family witnessed a street crime. They secretly followed the criminals to their lair before coming back to raise the alarm. They are now famous and loved by all!
You did not attend the banquet, allowing its organisers to increase their influence.
The other parties do not appreciate your ruining the event.
You have shown class and impressed all parties, but the organisers of the banquet also gained influence.

Excerpt from 'The River Eternal', Prologue 
 by Gaius Tetricus 

Time itself can be perceived as a river, flowing in a single direction, dragging men with its current like so many pieces of driftwood. Some men are small, insignificant even, and are resigned to being carried by the water of time without even a sigh; others are heavier and bulkier. Such men grow as they float downstream and at some point they may reach such size that they alter the course of the river itself. I, Gaius Pius Esuvius Tetricus, am one such man and in this book I shall attempt to relate the story of other men of this ilk. Study it diligently, oh noble reader, and pick the ripe fruits of knowledge for yourself...""

Excerpt from 'The River Eternal', Epilogue 
 by Gaius Tetricus 

…and the times are hard, the river flows slowly, thick with the blood of dead men. The lands of Rome are torn apart, our people are beleaguered and frightened. Still the Roman state will persevere. In this book I have outlined what needs to be done, the sacrifices that have to be made and I have based it all on truths from our glorious history. The war is constant and once it ends our true task begins. The task of rebuilding what was already razed to thee ground. A Republic reborn! With me, Gaius Pius Esuvius Tetricus, along with my son as consuls. For this is the Roman way.""

The Carthaginians claim they respect your right to rule over your own seas. However, they appear deeply offended as they leave. At the same time, your noblemen respect your stance of standing up to random demands from bearded foreigners.

The name ‘Dionysus’ invites a smile; the festival held in his honour is a celebration, where much happiness abounds. We practice the Rural Dionysia, whose origins lie far back through the midst of time. Although it is winter, we celebrate the cultivation of the vines and the fruit they produce. A splendid, elaborate procession is the centrepiece of the festivities, followed by singing and dancing competitions. There may also be theatre, but only at the largest settlements.

With your blessing, the warships of Carthage sail along your coastline, methodically torching any pirate vessel they come across. While you have gained favour with the Carthaginians, as a result, your noblemen frown upon what they consider a sign of weakness.
Both noblemen and commoners alike are very pleased with your decision not to sell the Veneti horses to the foreigners.

Both noblemen and commoners alike are very pleased with your decision not to sell Veneti horses to the foreigners. Unfortunately, the foreigners are a vengeful bunch, and defame you before your neighbours!

…leave it to mother. It is indeed the duty of a mother to take care of everything that her child dislikes or fears. That includes, but sadly is not limited to, fighting insects the size of rodents. When I managed to put down the beast of a moth, I felt Wahballatus crawl up behind me and behold the corpse with fright. "Go to bed now, pupil of my eye," I told him, "...and perhaps keep the curtains closed tonight.""

As soon as Wahballat passed the sentence, a brief silence fell over the hall. First, the sorry merchant sobbed, then a muttering of approval came from the crowd. Then the guards dragged the criminal away as my son looked on, his eyes suddenly full of smouldering embers.

I embraced my son and wept openly as his body shuddered in my arms. We knelt on the floor, servants trembling with fright gathered around, but nobody dared ask what was wrong. I remember that we held a ceremony honouring the dead sparrow in the temple of Baal the next day. Wahballat was sullen and silent for at least two weeks.

As soon as Wahballat passed the sentence, a brief silence fell over the hall. First, the merchant breathed a sigh of relief, then a muttering of approval came from the crowd. Then guards dragged the criminal away as my son observed the situation with the impartial expression of a judge.

Wahballat was overcome with glee at the sight of the peacock's colourful tail. His laughter rings in my ears still. Quickly, my son and the bird became the closest of friends. As much as the servants loved their little king, some of them grew to resent the daily cricket hunt that was needed in order to keep the royal fowl well fed.

As soon as Wahballat passed the sentence, a brief silence fell over the hall. First, the merchant gasped in surprise, then a muttering of approval came from the crowd. Then guards escorted the criminal out of the room. I spoke with him later that night and he did drop a few names. The accomplices were rounded up and it was again up to Wahballat to decide their fate. There was no place for mercy this time.

The little lion cub did not look like much. A playful, clumsy, overgrown kitten. Yet Wahballat took great fancy in him and kept the animal close by his side at all times. My son and his lion were a sight to behold as they roamed the palace court solemnly; courtiers and foreign emissaries spoke of the pair with awe and respect.

I started talking and soon enough his tears dried up. I explained about birds of prey, their keen eyesight, their sharp talons and beaks. A man must be like a falcon sometimes and grab what he needs. Unless his quarry is too heavy and might slow his flight." I then left him to mull over my cryptic words. My son is an intelligent boy, no doubt."

…kill it, I finished, then I took off my sandal and handed it to him. He looked a bit startled, his walk was a bit stiff as he went towards the moth. The first hit missed, but the second was spot on - there was no need for a third. When Wahballat gave me back my sandal, I saw a smile on his face - the smile of someone who had overcome his fear.

The animal I bought from a Nabatean merchant, who claimed this was the smartest little creature in all the world. Initially, Wahballat seemed unimpressed, but when the monkey stole the helmet of a guardsman, then filled it with dates from a fruit bowl, my son burst out laughing. In the following days everyone was talking lovingly of the little king and his mischievous beastie.

This is his lot in life," I told Wahballat calmly. "The sparrow is doomed to die in falcon claws, a falcon is doomed to starve to death if he does not manage to find prey. Weep not, for there is no need. Both birds played their part as was written." He seemed smitten by my words and from this day forward he showed a determination of which there had been no sign before."

As soon as Wahballat passed the sentence, a brief silence fell over the hall. First the merchant gasped in surprise, then a similar gasp came from the crowd. The criminal was free to go and hurried off never to be heard of or seen again. In the following days, people spoke of Wahballat's lenience, wondering whether its cause was a good heart or lunacy.

…open the window over there and let it fly away. Wahballat did so and, seeing that the moth kept close by the lamp, he blew out the flame. In the gloom, the noise of flapping wings dissipated into the distance and my son giggled. He certainly felt clever and so did I."

The animal was an Arabian breed, thin-legged and slender, black as cloudy night. When he first saw the horse, Wahballat lost his breath. For me\?" he rasped and slowly trod forward. In the following days, the foal became a trusted friend to my son and rumour had it that Wahballat was bound to become a horseman of great renown."

…fetch the servants. Wahballat smiled awkwardly as if wondering why he had not thought of it first. Then he yelled and servants and guardsmen poured into the hall. One of the spearmen carefully and masterfully pierced the insect then showed its corpse to Wahballat on the tip of his weapon. "Outstanding work," proclaimed the little king solemnly, "thou shall be rewarded!" So majestic was he that the soldier fell down to his knees and thanked him profusely."

I admit, I might have been harsher than was needed. Is it fitting for a king to cry over such an insignificant matter\?" I yelled. "War comes and tomorrow you may see the death of those closest to you. What then\? Waste not a single tear! Not ever!" He appeared humbled by my words yet I saw he understood me. From that day on, an iron streak appeared in his character, one that was not there before."

Honour is freedom. Indeed, what freedom has the coward, the traitor\? He who murders or steals\? No, my friend, only the honourable can be free." Kartir's eyebrows arched in mild surprise. "A most intriguing answer, oh light from heaven, but how could I expect any less from a truly honourable king\? Do forgive me, I beg!" Then we were back to talking about horses. Still, I felt odd."

A noble choice, oh lord," Kartir exclaimed. "Your father, Shapur, blessed be he, was a great warrior and never shunned a battle. His blood is in your veins, every act of yours is a display of his decisiveness." He then returned to his musing on philosophers without mentioning my choice any further."

Upon hearing my answer, Kartir smiled. This is exactly what the king did," he said. "He watched the bird in admiration, listened to its song and laughed and wept.  After hearing this story, his people praised the good heart of their lord. Indeed, you are most wise, oh pinnacle of kings!""

A noble choice, oh lord," Kartir exclaimed. "This name has not been used for a long time, yet time cannot erase its original meaning. A man of good fame. A king, if you allow me to rephrase, a leader. In other words: you, King of Kings!" He then returned to his musing on philosophers without mentioning my choice any further."

The crown," I uttered, "for it gives a man the right to rule over his fellow men. But it carries great peril for its bearer, in case he becomes unworthy." Kartir seemed pleased. "My gracious master! You truly are wise beyond your years!" He then took all the items and left in a hurry, as I wondered at the brevity of his visit."

A noble choice, oh lord," Kartir exclaimed. "Your grandfather, Ardashir, brought your family to prominence. Nothing prevented him from attaining power... not even his own brother." After that ominous remark, he returned to his musing on philosophers without mentioning my choice any further."

Only he who can destroy a thing is its master," I explained. "Therefore, a man who can destroy everything is a master of everything and is thus free." Kartir nodded, absorbing my answer. "Thus you are free as the existence of all your subjects is in your hands!" he exclaimed. Then we were back to talking about horses. Still, I felt odd."

Upon hearing my answer, Kartir smiled. This is exactly what the king did," he said. "He ordered the servants to prepare a trap and they caught the bird on the very next day. All around the land, his people marvelled at the singing bird in the grand royal palace. You are most wise, oh pinnacle of kings!""

The coin," I uttered, "for with enough of it, a man can be bought and sold. No deed will seem too vile if his eyes are blinded by the gleam of gold." Kartir seemed pleased. "My gracious master! You truly are wise beyond your years!" He then took all the items and left in a hurry, as I wondered at the brevity of his visit."

A noble choice, oh lord," Kartir exclaimed, "for your name is blessed indeed. Many other kings of that name may inherit your throne in the future, yet your power and grandeur shall forever remain unsurpassed." He then returned to his musing on philosophers without mentioning my choice any further."

Upon hearing my answer, Kartir smiled. This is exactly what the king did," he said. "He observed the bird carefully and when it flew to its nest, he followed it silently. And, in the nest, there were three eggs, each hatched into another magnificent bird. Thus the king came to own many birds with feathers like fire and eyes like sparkling jewels. All around the land, his people marvelled at the royal flock and their lord's ingenuity. You are most wise, oh pinnacle of kings!""

The pen," I uttered, "for with it, I may show mercy to a criminal or pronounce a death sentence over an innocent." Kartir seemed pleased. "My gracious master! You truly are wise beyond your years!" He then took all the items and left in a hurry, as I wondered at the brevity of his visit."

He is free, who does his duty. His duty is his purpose and to fulfil it, the man must exert his every skill. This is his freedom - the freedom of choosing how to act." Kartir nodded, absorbing my answer. "Thus, you are free as you can choose how to enact your heavenly duty of being our master!" he exclaimed. Then we were back to talking about horses. Still, I felt odd."

The dagger," I uttered, "for it facilitates murder, both concealed in nocturnal shadows and in broad daylight." Kartir seemed pleased. "My gracious master! You truly are wise beyond your years!" He then took all the items and left in a hurry, as I wondered at the brevity of his visit."

A man is not free if he follows orders. Therefore, a man is free only if he gives orders instead." Kartir nodded, absorbing my answer. "Thus, you are free as no man alive could give you orders, oh flower of kings!" he exclaimed. Then we were back to talking about horses. Still, I felt odd."

Upon hearing my answer, Kartir smiled. This is exactly what the king did," he said. "He ordered the servants to fetch him his bow and shot an arrow straight through the heart of the bird. All around the land, his people lauded his marksmanship. You are most wise, oh pinnacle of kings!""

Standing armies and outposts can help increase the safety of provinces, while certain reforms can make settlements more independent and self-sufficient.

Have I not enough on my mind that you disturb me\?" I asked. "Or are you perhaps unable to deal with so simple an affair\? If the boy is a thief indeed, so punish him, if not, set him free. Go now and trouble me no more!" The Legionaries left, ashamed, taking the boy with them. What happened to him I do not know."

So, you intend to present this list to the people in it and claim I have their destruction in mind\? Is it because of what I said\? Do you pay no attention to my words\? For it was my anger that spoke and not I. Retire to your chambers in peace." When he left I sent for Mucapor immediately. Our conversation was short and meaningful. The very next evening the secretary was found in a ditch, his neck broken. The man should have laid off the wine."

As I recall, I handed the sword to a nearby attendant then turned my attention to the fallen Illyrian. Brave you are to face your Emperor and not flinch at that," I told him. "Yet, you still have much to learn about swordplay - I suggest you start right now." I then strode off, leaving the soldier to scramble to his feet."

So, you intend to present this list to the people in it and claim I have their destruction in mind\? All because I have accused you justly\? You only add to your sins, you miserable gnat! The court convenes tomorrow! Pray to whatever gods you think might help you!" Guards were summoned and the hapless secretary was taken away."

I remember that day still. My fingers ran across the clasps of the helm and took it off in a single fluid motion. The cool breeze blew against my face. I turned towards Mucapor and said Sometimes it is good to breathe, eh, old friend\?" "Indeed, my lord. Almost always," he answered. The soldiers before us seemed bewildered. Many of the new recruits, I realised, had never seen my face before."

So, you intend to present this list to the people in it and claim I have their destruction in mind\? Indeed, you have lived for far too long!" My pugio left its sheathe with a wheeze. The secretary did not even try to defend himself. When I called the guards to remove the body of the traitor, they had no questions to ask."

I remember that day still. As I answered Mucapor, I smiled, yet my smile was concealed beneath my mask. It seems that our lord, Sol Invictus, bestows upon us too much of his glorious warmth today. His benevolence is hard to bear, yet I am grateful." Mucapor nodded in understanding. Not long after the itch was gone."

As I recall, I threw down the training sword and drew my own. A gasp came from the crowd around us and dissipated when I plunged the metal blade into the ground. There," I proclaimed as I helped the Illyrian get back on his feet "A worthy reward for a worthy soldier. Carry this weapon with pride, use it to smite the enemies of Rome and remember the day you fought an Emperor!" I then strode off. The silence around the training field was absolute."

I remember that day still. I remember the anger I felt at this most insignificant itch. An itch! Discomfort! Bah! A true Emperor, a soldier of Rome, can overcome any discomfort. I did not answer Mucapor's enquiry and continued reviewing the troops. When the itch disappeared I did not even notice.

The man with the iron face, eh\?" I smiled wryly. "You have found him, so what do you want with him\?" We then talked for awhile. The boy shared a few amusing stories from the surrounding countryside along with the names of certain people from my camp who sold military rations to ordinary folk. Most intriguing indeed. I thanked the boy and sent him off in peace."

As I recall, I prodded his chest with the wooden sword. You fight well! With soldiers like you, Rome needs not fear any enemy." He scrambled to his feet as the soldiers around the training ground cheered us both."

Thief or no thief, I care not," I judged. "This boy has no business being in the camp. Whip him and whip him until he loses his audacity." I admit, I might have sounded a bit more enraged than I actually was, for the Legionary hurried off to the tent, dragging the boy behind him. In the blink of an eye he had lost all of the defiance I had imagined he exuded."

I remember that day still. I turned the face of Sol Invictus towards Mucapor and said A leader of men ought to give them his undivided attention. Are you a leader of men, Mucapor\?" He mumbled an apology and said nothing more. Good man, this one. Obeys easily. As for the itch, it slowly subsided."

As I recall, it only took a single blow to the temple. I then strode off, dropping the training sword on the ground. A weird purple veil shimmered at the edge of my eyes. By the end of the day, the story of what had occurred flew around the camp and became bizarrely twisted - soldiers claimed that the Illyrian had challenged me in an attempt to slay me and I had then given him his due.

A great need must have driven the boy to commit the crime of theft," I mused, "...and it is the duty of the Emperor to alleviate the suffering of his people. In the name of Sol Invictus, give this boy all the food he can carry and let him go." The Legionaries were astounded as they set off to obey my command, yet by nightfall tales of my generosity had spread around camp."

So, you intend to present this list to the people in it and claim I have their destruction in mind\? You foolish man! To what extreme does fear drive us\? Betray your lord, your country; burn the parchment on that brazier over there, then just leave. I expect to see you fulfilling your duties tomorrow." The secretary could scarcely belief his luck. Off he went into the night and in the coming days, although I kept my eye on him, I could not find any fault in his work."
Talks with Kartir - Prologue

This member of the family is introduced to a lucrative investment opportunity. They borrow heavily to cover their share of the deal. A week later, things look decidedly promising. Success seems imminent!

After being visited by an exotic traveller, this family member becomes convinced that somewhere there is a great treasure of secret knowledge which will bring them prosperity and long life. They now spend all their time try to locate it!

This member of the family was told by astrologers that they were born under a lucky star. Good luck is contagious, so there is a chance their good fortune will spill over and benefit the rest of the family.

After a night of heavy drinking and solemn observation of the sky, this family member became convinced that they can predict the future. The rest of the family is still evaluating the evidence.

This member of the family has always been well respected for their wisdom. Recently, they were invited to give their opinion on a complicated philosophical matter. This member of the family has become convinced that they are barren and unable to produce offspring. As a result, they progressively lose their vigour and hope for starting a family.

This family member was a guest to a dinner, given by an exotic eastern trader. They were served a type of wine which was apparently enchanting. Now, our kin refuses to drink any other type of liquid. Annoyance is in the air everywhere they go.

This family member is feeling melancholic, having read a lot of poetry and having had vivid, lucid dreams. This means they are mostly absent, in mind at least, when there are family matters to discuss.

A servant from the house of a rival family has been discussing their secrets in the market. This member of our family was present and managed to absorb the valuable information. They have always displayed an instinct for the finest aspects of the political game.

The Eagle represents the Legion's glory and will one day be its legacy. Without it, there is no bond keeping the Legionaries together. My husband, Odaenathus, was a powerful man. Single-minded in his strength, he ploughed his way through life, taking what he wanted - lands, riches, glory. When traitors conspired against him they did so in fear. They did not expect their plot to succeed. They also did not expect me to fight for Odaenathus' kingdom and power. I have dealt with them all, one way or another. Now I rule Palmyra along with my only son, Wahballat. King and queen, mother and child, standing amidst a storm of sand and blood. I will do what I must to see my son grow into a man feared and respected from Rome to Ctesiphon. And I will succeed. This I swear.

I remember that once, in Armenia, a wise man visited my court. An astrologist by trade, he explained the stars had prophesised great future for me. In time, I would receive the title of 'Shahanshah'. What was his name\? I do not recall. I remember rewarding him with a purse full of gold, as is fitting for an omen this good. Yet within, I laughed. True, I was a son of the old Shahanshah, but I had two elder brothers. It seemed unthinkable. And now I sit upon the throne, the old priest Kartir at my side, my courtiers attend my every whim. I am the King of Kings. The burden of my father and grandfather's greatness lies heavy upon my shoulders. Yet is it not true that no man is burdened with more than he could carry\?

It is difficult to admit oneself a fool. Yet a fool I must have been since I doubted Kartir's honesty even a little. The priest has grown to be a stout supporter of my rule, approving each step I take. Sometimes I am tempted to make a mistake on purpose, if only to see how he would react. However, would this fit the dignified position of a Shahanshah\? Certainly not! Ah! The satisfaction of having a wise and loyal councillor. It does ease the burden of the crown immensely.

It takes considerable effort to bring the statue down and break it into pieces. The people fear that your decision has invoked the wrath of a stone giant; they care little that your actions seem to have no ill effects.

The merchant has returned to the city empty-handed, miserably offering to pay his debt with his life. He could have simply vanished, but instead chose to return and face the situation, one way or another. Apparently honest men don't make good merchants… Such is the way of the world!

In the end, the merchant's endeavour proved ten times more profitable than initially forecast! However, merchants are merchants - he has paid us our due and nothing more, despite his good fortune. Nevertheless, it was still a good deal…

In the  end, the merchant's endeavour proved even more profitable than initially imagined. He was so happy that he not only paid our share, but also provided a considerable bonus as a tribute, in return for your belief in him when others didn't.
