The man turned out to be a foreign agent. Although that particular province increased its wealth, our exports will suffer. Sadly, for the time being, we have lost our lucrative trade monopoly over the area.
The foreign merchant has bought up almost all last season's produce! Local trade is thriving!
The man looks disgruntled but returns to his company to discuss your offer. Five days later, he returns... They accept! \n\nThe mercenaries have strengthened the ranks of your army considerably.
The mercenary company have joined the ranks of your army, bolstering its skills and experience considerably!

Foolish as it may have seemed, an open, public conversation with the king may have persuaded him to see the error of his ways. With all his bloodthirstiness, Tarquinius should have been aware that the people greatly resented him. In truth, the king was exiled and when he returned in force - defeated in battle. In this way the Republic was established, so long ago.""

For Brutus and his like-minded comrades, the solution to Caesar's dictatorship was simple: the man had to die. This involved conspiracy, treachery, spilling of blood, yet no deed is vile or repulsive when it is done for the sake of the Republic and its sanctity. However, the murder simply postponed the creation of the Empire, instead of preventing it completely.""

His conspiracy made public, Catiline seemed to have only one option, a single way to exit the situation and prevent further shame upon his name: suicide. His associates would then disperse and no more Roman blood would have been shed. Instead, he chose to fight. It is unfortunate that such a courageous man failed to abide by Republican laws.""

For Brutus and his like-minded comrades, the solution to Caesar's dictatorship could have been simpler: Caesar's regime could be weakened. This would have been hard, as Caesar was both cunning and loved by the common people. However, if correctly executed, this approach would have lessened the likelihood of violence. Instead, they chose a bloodier path and Julius Caesar was slain by their hands instead. Yet the murder simply postponed the creation of the Empire, instead of preventing it completely.""

Sulla had to act quickly. He had proven himself worthy to rule over Rome, yet a man loyal to the Republic would have trusted the virtues of the Roman Senate and rejected the power bestowed upon him; his Legions would have been a sufficient deterrent against treachery by ambitious men. Instead, Sulla attempted to heal the wounds of the state via legislation, before ultimately giving up his power and retiring. Perhaps too late, at that.""

For Brutus and his like-minded comrades, the solution to Caesar's dictatorship could have been simpler: the man could be exiled. In his absence, they could have strengthened their position and empowered the Senate to thwart further attempts to crown a new Roman king. Instead, they chose a bloodier path and Julius Caesar was slain by their hands. Yet the murder simply postponed the creation of the Empire, instead of preventing it completely.""

Sulla had to act quickly. He had proven himself worthy to rule over Rome and was in a position to disband the Senate and create a new institution, a new order even. A similar council of a different function and structure would have sufficed to prevent or at least postpone further civil strife. Yet, although Sulla attempted to heal the wounds of the state via legislation, he ultimately gave up his power and retired.  We can only surmise what could have happened had he acted otherwise.""

His conspiracy made public, Catiline could have considered self-imposed exile. A travel to distant lands would have enabled him to bide his time, gain powerful friends and make another attempt at toppling the Republic he viewed as corrupt. Instead, he chose to fight. It is unfortunate that such a courageous man failed to abide by Republican laws.""

Perilous as it may have seemed, it was possible to kill the king. His kin would remain and they would either hunger for revenge or be humbled by the realisation that death awaited them as well if they were to oppose Brutus. In truth, the king was exiled and when he returned in force he was defeated in battle. In this way, the Republic was established, so long ago.""

Sulla had to act quickly. He had proven himself worthy to rule over Rome and only needed to ratify a new title for himself. In this way, he could rise above the others and no longer allow the Republic to be torn apart by disputes and individual ambition. Yet, although Sulla attempted to heal the wounds of the state via legislation, he ultimately gave up his power and retired. We can only surmise what could have happened had he acted otherwise.""

His conspiracy made public, Catiline should have relied on eloquence and renounce his own deeds. Only by pretending to be honest could he survive the repercussions he was about to face. If he managed to trick his opponents into believing his remorse was earnest, Catiline could plot further, in greater secrecy, bitter lessons well learned. Instead, he chose to fight. It is unfortunate that such a courageous man failed to abide by Republican laws.""

For Brutus and his like-minded comrades, the solution to Caesar's dictatorship could have been simpler: convince Caesar that his rule was illegal. The Roman state was a republic and a republic it had to stay! Neither the Senate nor the people would have obeyed a new king and the conspirators knew that. Instead, they chose a bloodier path and Julius Caesar was slain by their hands. Yet the murder simply postponed the creation of the Empire, instead of preventing it completely.""

Exiling the king was the only proper way to resolve the situation. In addition to what common sense and honour dictated, the king was away from Rome at the time, so in order to banish him, he only had to be denied entry to the great city. Certainly, the tyrant did not give in - he found allies and returned in force. It was his defeat in battle that sealed the beginning of the Republic, so long ago.""

Sulla acted quickly. He proclaimed his enemies to be enemies of the state and compiled their names in a list, available in the Roman forum. Any Roman citizens could expect rewards for killing or helping the authorities prosecute any man from that list. Certainly this was a violent way to resolve matters, yet in times of desperation one must not fear resorting to violence.""

Slow as it may have seemed, undermining the king's authority was a reasonable enough choice. His opponents could assemble, act in coordination and gradually chip at Tarquinius' influence until his control was reduced to naught. Once the king and his family had lost power, they could be replaced by a Republican government. In truth, the king was exiled and when he returned in force - defeated in battle. In this way the Republic was established, so long ago.""

Even faced with insurmountable odds, honour demanded that Catiline fought to the death. He mustered all the troops still loyal to him and met the forces of Antonius Hybrida on the field of battle. He perished the way a Roman warrior should, by the blades of his enemies. It is unfortunate that such a courageous man failed to abide by Republican laws.""

The refugees are starting to integrate into society by themselves. Time will tell if their presence is mutually beneficial. They expect nothing from you but, on the other hand, you should not expect anything from them either!

The survivors are now a functioning part of your society. As you might expect, after losing their homeland they are bent on not letting this happen again! So far, things are going well - the local province is thriving.

The refugees didn't put up much resistance and were easily subdued. However, facing enslavement after also losing their homes has broken their spirit. To be honest, we doubt they will prove a productive workforce.
The refugees were forced to flee once more in search of a lord more merciful and pious. As you might expect, their prayers to the gods curse your name!

Our workers have found something! One of the unearthed chambers turned out to be a burial chamber containing the tomb of some ancient ruler. We may never discover his name, as none of the inscriptions can be deciphered, but we have found his priceless crown jewels!
Ohrmazd-Yimki
Our workers dug the site for days... Alas, the ruins have turned out to be just a poor village, containing nothing but the stench of disappointment!
Business Venture
Business Venture
After a sizeable investment, the quality of the roads is much enhanced. Now, your armies can march much faster to their destination.
The father is fined, then reprimanded in public. The pious among the people breathe a sigh of relief, as justice has been served. However, the father now holds a grudge against you.
Prayers are uttered daily; libations and sacrifices are made with zeal. The people are content with your efforts, yet still there are fewer sheep...
All recruits are forced to swear an oath of bravery - to fight to the last and never retreat from the enemy. They enter the ranks with conviction in their hearts.
Small militia groups are organised to watch over the most troublesome roads in case of bandits. This improves overall security in Samnite lands.
The son is publicly reprimanded and then flogged. Everyone seems pleased with your decision, agreeing that the young man only has himself to blame.
Many sheep are sent to Delphi to be sacrificed. This brings the Samnites wealth, yet we might have sold slightly more of our livestock than is prudent.
Everyone is allowed to join the army. The benefit of this is that many recruits come well equipped, thus the overall cost of recruitment is significantly cheaper.
Traders soon learn to travel along the seldom-used mountain passes. Those that make it through alive find their profits increased.

It is not too hard to find an innocent man to blame and prosecute. The commoners suspect that this has all been a ruse and grow restless. However, the nobles are grateful for your tact and openly show support for your rule.

It takes considerable effort to cut down several forests. Afterwards, there remains sufficient pasture available for our four-legged friends to graze. However, less trees will spell trouble for Samnite industry.
Luckily, the series of bandit attacks was merely a temporary state of affairs - traders can once again travel in relative safety.
A special tax is levied in order to increase the number of temples, and therefore sacrifices made. Despite the cries of the angry, pious people, a portion of the tax goes directly to the treasury.
Despite the angry shouts of priests and the pious, the shepherds guide their livestock onto the sacred spaces. Hopefully, the gods will not take too much offence!
Following a period of proper training, your sailors show that the spirit of the Sherden mariners is still alive and well.
Although the giant seems to pay no heed to the abundance of gifts offered in its honour, the people feel that they have done their part and breathe a sigh of relief.
Following a period of proper training, your men show that the spirit of the Sherden looters is still alive and well.

Armed guards observe the statue for many days, yet nothing extraordinary happens. Although the rumours are obviously false, the stories begin to spread; every warrior feels proud to march next to these men.
Following a period of proper training, your troops show that the spirit of the Sherden warriors is still alive and well.
Following a period of proper training, your men show that the spirit of the Sherden is still alive and well.
Business Venture
Business Venture
Contrary to expectations, this year the river is shallow. We will suffer some losses, but thankfully we didn't waste effort clearing the extra land in preparation.
Disaster! Against all expectations, there has been a period of intense drought. Unfortunately, the recently-cleared land will have to remain deserted…
The rains destroy crops and livelihoods. Homes are gone, and loved ones disappear in the rushing waters, never to be seen again.
Corinth has won the war! The city has expressed their gratitude by lending us their best general.\n\n Epaminondas of Corinth has joined our faction!

Try as you might, your words cannot penetrate their thick plebeian skulls. With furious shouts, and more than a few thrown vegetables, you are driven from the podium. Meanwhile, several patricians observe the scene, unfazed by events.

Upon being given free meals, the plebs are ecstatic, as they would be at any handout. They stuff themselves with the bread and fruits, carrying off as much as they can back to their homes. The patricians discuss the scene with seething anger – why should they pay for food that has not been earned\?

You may have decided to bring more Scythians in just to spite the plebs, as this is exactly what happens! The crowds grow more numerous and noisier by the minute. Meanwhile, the patricians, discussing the matter among themselves, think that you have gone too far this time…

The young patrician is publicly admonished. As the speech ends, the crowd starts to murmur their annoyance. Apparently, they believe they are witnessing a charade and nothing more. No patrician is present to comment on the scene.

The most prominent plebs are assigned to check for fire hazards; these measures appear sufficient, as no fire erupts on the day or indeed the day after. As contentment rises among the plebs, the patricians are resentful that the lowly classes have been given more rights.

The plebs are angry at your decision to bring in even more Greeks. However, upon seeing how quickly they work, their rage wanes. Meanwhile, a group of patricians, disgruntled with the quality of the Greeks' construction work, give speeches criticising you before the Senate.

Try as you might, your words cannot penetrate their thick plebeian skulls. With furious shouts, and more than a few thrown vegetables, you are driven from the podium. Meanwhile, several patricians observe the scene, unfazed by events.

Your speech gives a broader perspective to both plebs and patricians on the man in question and his virtues, both real and imaginary. In the end, however, the mob seethes with rage at the hypocrisy. Once the day is over, several patricians congratulate you, assuring you that you have done what is best for Rome.

In an emotional and eloquent speech, you manage to divert the plebs' attention with other subects such as, war, famine and those insolent Etruscans. As the crowd of plebs disperses, the patricians nod their approval.

Upon being given free meals, the plebs are ecstatic, as they would be at any handout. They stuff themselves with the bread and fruits, carrying off as much as they can back to their homes. The patricians discuss the scene with mild resentment – why should they pay for food that has not been earned\?

Although you might have decided to bring in more Scythians just to spite the plebs, it doesn't work that way. The plebs gradually grow to appreciate the foreigners, much to the patricians' satisfaction. Everyone seems happy, which is a rare thing indeed!

The young patrician is publically admonished. The speech ends among the cheers of the plebs - they have apparently viewed the whole spectacle with delight. The patricians, on the other hand, are visibly appalled by your decision.

The most prominent plebs are assigned to check for fire hazards; these measures appear sufficient, as no fire erupts on the day or indeed the day after. The patricians have paid no attention to the affair, it seems.

Upon hearing your decision, a throng of furious plebs fills the forum, cursing your name. However, they do not attempt to disrupt the foreigners’ work, the effects of which are soon visible all over the city. The patricians, meanwhile, are too busy with their own matters to be involved in any way.

In an emotional and eloquent speech, you manage to divert the plebs' attention with other subjects, such as war, famine and those insolent Etruscans. As the crowd disperses, the patricians do the very same, but make little or no comment.

Your speech gives a broader perspective to both plebs and patricians on the man in question and his virtues, both real and imaginary. In the end, however, their suspicions are allayed and everyone goes home happy.
Happy Workers
Unhappy Workers
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, many nobles agree that it was entertainment worthy of the gods and regard you with great respect now.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, the population celebrate the event with a spontaneous feast that lasts for some time.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, many of the participants rush to join the army, with fighting fervour still burning in their hearts.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, many of the participants rush to join the army - the tournament has taught them much about the warrior arts.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, many of the participants rush to join the army - many carry weapons belonging to their defeated opponents.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, many veteran warriors show greater confidence and skill in their trade.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, tales of the great event resound throughout every corner of your lands, no matter how distant.
The tournament is truly magnificent. Regardless of whether they participated or witnessed the event, many of your warriors feel energised, as if the breath of the ancient gods drives them forward.
The tournament is truly magnificent. After the dust settles, a constant flow of new warriors ensures the ranks of your armies remain at full strength.

The troops break up several secret criminal meetings, and the ring leaders are taken to justice. The plebs appear to be pleased for the moment, while the patricians' opposition against you intensifies...

Upon being given free meals, the plebs are ecstatic, as they would be at any handout. They stuff themselves with the bread and fruits, carrying off as much as they can back to their homes. The patricians discuss the scene with mild amusement and not much else.

Despite having been so vocal, the plebs pay little mind to the patrician as he leads the Scythians from the city. Your informants warn you that on his return, the insulted slave owner began talking, propagating dissent amongst his peers.

No time is lost - the bold young patrician is deprived of his senatorial rank. The plebs are satisfied that their plight has been eased, while the patricians express their distrust of your political integrity!

The plebs hear you out and your speech calms them down. At least someone is doing something," someone says. The patricians suspect that the solution will be at their expense – for some reason, they are uneasy!"
Once the Greek builders leave, the plebs go to their homes, content at having been acknowledged. At the same time, the patricians are a little disturbed about your decision...

The plebs are on the verge of heading to Mons Sacer, as they did in the old days; only the speeches of a few patricians bring sense to the crowd. Later, these very same patricians claim that you definitely lack governmental skills, despite the substantial funds flowing into the treasury.

All accusations are refuted and the case is closed. Unfortunately, the plebs do not think the same, and protest your decision almost every day. Meanwhile, the patricians are rather pleased with your willingness to fight for their interests.
The troops break up several secret criminal meetings, and the ring leaders are taken to justice. The plebs cheer with admiration at these measures, while the patricians begin to plot your downfall...

Upon being given free meals, the plebs are ecstatic, as they would be at any handout. They stuff themselves with the bread and fruits, carrying off as much as they can back to their homes. The patricians discuss the scene with mild amusement and not much else.

The throng of plebs cheers as the patricians takes the Scythians away from the city. Your informants warn you that after returning, the insulted slave owner has begun plotting his vengeance in secret.

No time is lost - the bold young patrician is deprived of his senatorial rank. The plebs are extremely happy that their plight has been eased, while the patricians condemn you as a simple-minded populist!
The plebs hear you out and your speech calms them down. Perhaps the issue was not that big to begin with\? The patricians congratulate you on your eloquence but do little else.

Once the Greek builders leave, the plebs openly express their joy at having been acknowledged. At the same time, the patricians are a little disturbed about your decision, some predicting that at this rate the plebs will be the masters of Rome soon enough...

The plebs are on the verge of heading to Mons Sacer, as they did in the old days; only the speeches of a few patricians bring sense to the crowd. Later, these very same patricians pat you on the back, as substantial funds are now flowing into the treasury.

All accusations are refuted and the case is closed. Unfortunately, the plebs do not think the same, and protest your decision daily. Their tribunes ride the tide of their anger well, however. Meanwhile, the patricians are delighted with your willingness to fight for their interests.

Finally, the day has come. Dressed in warrior's garb, a sword at his side, Wahballat shall ride out to smite the enemies of Palmyra, just as his father did years before. That is it. Whatever happens to me, let it be known that I succeeded and my oath was fulfilled.

Finally, the day has come. Dressed in warrior's garb, a sword at his side, Wahballat shall ride out to smite the enemies of Palmyra, just as his father did years before. That is it. Whatever happens to me, let it be known that I succeeded and my oath was fulfilled.

Finally, the day has come. Dressed in warrior's garb, a sword at his side, Wahballat shall ride out to smite the enemies of Palmyra, just as his father did years before. That is it. Whatever happens to me, let it be known that I succeeded and my oath was fulfilled.

Finally, the day has come. Dressed in warrior's garb, a sword at his side, Wahballat shall ride out to smite the enemies of Palmyra, just as his father did years before. That is it. Whatever happens to me, let it be known that I succeeded and my oath was fulfilled.
The patrician promises to curb the activities of his shadowy associates. Upon hearing the news, the crowd of plebs disperses, among murmurs of approval.

In a public speech, you attempt to dispel the rumours of food shortage and you seem to be successful. Your words calm the plebs and the crowd disperses. The patricians show little support for you either, but do not attempt to undermine your authority.

Some plebeians fight back against the troops, but nobody is harmed. Their discontent keeps on simmering for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians view the whole situation as a minor nuisance!

Some plebeians fight back against the troops, but nobody is harmed. Their discontent keeps on simmering for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians view the whole situation as a minor nuisance!

Some plebeians fight back against the troops; several are injured and one is killed. Their anger keeps on boiling for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians appear amused!

Initially, the plebs view the Greeks with disdain and are not too eager to work with them. Their co-operation, however, has beneficial effects for a few senatorial homes around Rome. The patricians are rather pleased!

Pleasing a pleb is sometimes just as easy as angering one. In this case, a temporary tax reduction is sufficient to send everybody home, their faces stretched into silly grins. The patricians observe the proceedings with utter impartiality.

The investigation of the patrician lasts about a week, and as a result the man is found to be innocent. The plebs are glad that justice has triumphed, yet many patricians openly condemn your willingness to doubt the honesty of one who is noble-born.
The patrician promptly denies any involvement with the gang, yet the tide of criminal activity seems to abate. The plebs still grumble, nevertheless.

In a public speech you attempt to dispel the food shortage rumours yet to no avail. The plebs feel cheated by your words and do not even let you finish. The patricians show little support for you either, but do not attempt to undermine your authority.

Some plebeians fight back against the troops; several are injured and one is killed. Their anger keeps on boiling for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians appear amused!

Some plebeians fight back against the troops; several are injured and one is killed. Their anger keeps on boiling for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians appear amused!

Some plebeians fight back against the troops; several are injured and one is killed. Their anger keeps on boiling for a while, yet every attempt to hold a rally is thwarted by the army. The patricians appear amused!

Initially, the plebs view the Greeks with disdain, but gradually realise that foreign builders have a lot to teach them. Their co-operation has beneficial effects for many run-down buildings in and around Rome. As none of the buildings are owned by patricians, however, they are indifferent to the whole affair.

Pleasing a pleb is sometimes just as easy as angering one. In this case, a temporary tax reduction is sufficient to send everybody home, their faces stretched into silly grins. Some patricians, however, seriously doubt the practicality of this solution.

The investigation of the patrician lasts about a week, and as a result the man is convicted of embezzlement. The plebs are glad that justice has triumphed, yet many patricians convene in secret to discuss your decision. Some even declare that you are no longer useful to them...

Seven days in April; this is the length of ‘Cerealia,’ the festival in honour of our beloved Ceres. To ensure her benevolence, we celebrate in a fashion worthy of her divine stature. Each night we perform the ritual, whereby torches are attached to the tails of foxes and they are allowed to run about, symbolically cleansing the growing crops. Votive games are also held, and there are female dancers, dressed all in white. As you might expect, plenty of wine accompanies it all!

The plebs may have expected nothing to be done about the criminal gang, yet they are displeased nevertheless. The patricians, on the other hand, appreciate that you do not wish to look into their more… ‘unconventional’ activities.
Most plebs know that the rumours of food shortages are just rumours, yet feel discontent as nothing has been done by the authorities. Oddly enough, several patricians make speeches in your defence.

The plebs carry on demanding that something be done about those odd-smelling Scythians for quite a while. Their plebeian grumblings manage to find the ears of several of the patricians, who begin to view you with slight disdain.

The plebs express their rage during some noisy demonstrations, even blocking important city streets, preventing the flow of goods and services around the city. This leads to angry muttering among the patricians, whose finances could suffer if this situation is allowed to continue!

It takes the plebs several weeks to finally calm down. Before that, the rallies were held daily; the most vocal elements whipping the plebeians' anger to dangerous levels. The patricians, however, are completely unfazed!
The plebs are disappointed by your lack of interest but make no attempt to disrupt the Greeks, enabling them to get some work done. Meanwhile, the patricians seem uninterested in the occurrence.
It takes the plebs several weeks to finally calm down. As a matter of fact, everyone expected their anger to be more severe. The patricians, however, are completely unfazed!

The plebs continue to demand justice in the case of the corrupt politician – when nothing happens they mutter threats of succession and even violent retribution! The patricians are disturbed by this possibility and denounce your indecision.
The plebs are outraged with your apparent indifference regarding the criminal gang, while the patricians could not care less about the whole affair.
The plebs are outraged with your uwnillingness to solve the perceived food problems. At the same time, the patricians are clearly indifferent with the whole affair.

The plebs carry on demanding that something be done about those odd-smelling Scythians for quite a while. Nevertheless, their plebeian anger, however great, does little to stir the patricians one way or the other.

The plebs express their rage during some noisy demonstrations, even blocking important city streets, preventing the flow of goods and services around the city. Despite the upset, the patricians have little comment to make on the situation.

It takes the plebs several weeks to finally calm down. Before that, the rallies were held daily; the most vocal elements whipping the plebeians' anger to dangerous levels. After some plebs attempt to set fire to a patrician's home the entire Senate is abuzz, much to your distress.

The plebs are utterly enraged by your lack of interest and ensure that the Greeks’ work is disrupted. As a result, the foreigners are offended and leave. The patricians, meanwhile, seem disinterested in this occurrence.

It takes the plebs several weeks to finally calm down. Before that, the rallies were held daily; the most vocal elements whipping the plebeians' anger to dangerous levels. The patricians, however, are completely unfazed!

The plebs continue to demand justice in the case of the corrupt politician – when nothing happens a brief riot disrupts the activity in the Forum Boarium. Their peace interrupted, the patricians regard the raging crowd with mild disdain.
Our new selection of horses has improved our cavalry.
